Headline.Para: Behind Richard Gates' Guilty Plea in the Russia Probe; How the ex-Trump aide, facing financial and legal pressure from Special Prosecutor Robert Mueller, struck a plea deal on conspiracy

Snippet.Para: Nearly until Richard Gates walked into court to plead guilty to conspiracy in a deal with Special Counsel Robert Mueller, some of the former Trump's aide's closest friends didn't know he had sat for hours of interviews with investigators.

Headline.Para: Behind Richard Gates' Guilty Plea in the Russia Probe; How the ex-Trump aide, facing financial and legal pressure from Special Prosecutor Robert Mueller, struck a plea deal on conspiracy

LeadPara.Para: Nearly until Richard Gates walked into court to plead guilty to conspiracy in a deal with Special Counsel Robert Mueller, some of the former Trump's aide's closest friends didn't know he had sat for hours of interviews with investigators.
They believed he was still gearing up for a fight, according to interviews with multiple people familiar with the events.

TailParas.Para: New details on the outwardly chaotic days leading up to his decision to strike a deal with Mr. Mueller shed light on how the special counsel reeled him in, and how it nearly didn't happen.

The former campaign adviser to President Donald Trump in February became the third Trump associate to publicly admit to criminal misconduct and agree to cooperate in Mr. Mueller's probe into what U.S. intelligence officials say was

Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election. Mr. Mueller has now publicly charged a total of 19 people in the wide-ranging probe. The charges against the two men are unrelated to their work for the Trump campaign.

Mr. Gates' plea will likely strengthen Mr. Mueller's case against Paul Manafort, a former Trump campaign chairman, Mr. Gates' longtime business partner and a central figure in the probe. Mr. Manafort has denied the charges and is fighting them.

Since his plea on Feb. 23, Mr. Gates has recounted to friends a series of last minute phone calls that he told them ultimately convinced him to accept the agreement. The new details appear to reflect Mr. Gates' ambivalence about whether to fight the charges or plead guilty, which left him fumbling an interview with Mr. Mueller's team on Feb 1.

Mr. Gates blew through one deadline to respond by the special counsel's office, triggering a separate indictment. Even after his lawyer had reached a deal with prosecutors, Mr. Gates was telling friends he was going to go to trial.
The apparent confusion about Mr. Gates's status in the days before the plea seems to reflect the emotional, financial and legal pressures that were building against him.
Mr. Gates still owes more than $200,000 to lawyers. He also was facing a potential sentence of as much as 20 years on one count of conspiracy to launder money.

After rejecting multiple plea deals, Mr. Gates ultimately accepted one that dropped new tax and bank fraud charges but added one count of lying to the special counsel's office during the Feb. 1 interview.
Mr. Gates and Mr. Manafort, his longtime business partner, were arrested in Oct. 30 on a 12-count indictment obtained by Mr. Mueller's office in Washington, the first public charges in the inquiry.

The indictment accused them of laundering millions of dollars in income generated from their consulting work for a pro-Russian political party in Ukraine from 2006 through 2016 and failing to file reports on the lobbying work and on foreign bank accounts they allegedly controlled. Russia denies meddling in the 2016 campaign.
At the outset, Messrs. Gates and Manafort pleaded not guilty and prepared to fight the case.

When he was arrested, Mr. Gates dropped the lawyer who had represented him in the investigation, former Virginia federal prosecutor Michael Dry. He soon retained a trio of other former federal prosecutors that included Walter Mack, based in New York, and Annemarie McAvoy and Shanlon Wu, both based in Washington, D.C.

Mr. Gates talked to multiple lawyers and advisers about his case beyond those who were publicly registered to represent him, people familiar with the discussions said. On January 23, CNN reported that another lawyer, Tom Green, had visited Mr. Mueller's office on Mr. Gates' behalf.

Days later, on Feb. 1, Messrs Mack and Wu and Ms. McAvoy filed to immediately withdraw from the case, citing in court papers "irreconcilable differences" that had developed between them and Mr. Gates, which made their "effective representation...impossible." The court filing didn't say what those differences were.

It would be difficult for lawyers to adequately represent a defendant, however, if they were not privy to all of the defendant's discussions with prosecutors, since they would still be on the hook if anything went wrong in those discussions, experts said.
The judge overseeing the case, U.S. District Judge Amy Berman Jackson, called a sealed hearing to discuss the matter on Feb. 7, but made no decision on the lawyers' request to withdraw.

The following week, on Feb. 12, she ordered Mr. Gates to tell her by the following day at 5 p.m. whether he agreed with his lawyers' request to withdraw. In a filing representing himself, Mr. Gates asked for another week to answer the question.

Meanwhile, Mr. Mueller's office continued to pressure Messrs. Gates and Manafort, pursuing additional charges against the two in Washington. Mr. Mueller also obtained a separate indictment in Virginia accusing the pair of tax fraud and bank fraud.

As Judge Jackson awaited a response, Mr. Mueller's office presented Mr. Gates with a series of plea offers and deadlines by which to respond. Mr. Gates continued to hesitate, people familiar with the offers said, telling some friends he was going to fire Mr. Green.
Also swirling in the mix was yet another attorney. Mr. Gates spoke several times to another veteran trial lawyer, Barry Pollack, about the possibility of taking the case to trial.
But in the end, as Mr. Gates faced increasing financial pressures from unpaid legal bills, he decided to take a deal.

On Feb. 22, Mr. Green appeared on behalf of Mr. Gates, and Mr. Gates pleaded guilty the next day. The deal he ultimately agreed to included one count of conspiring against the U.S. by impeding the IRS.
That agreement added a second charge of lying to the special counsel's office stemming from the Feb. 1 interview. That was the same day Mr. Gates' legal team filed to withdraw from the case.

Mr. Green's ultimate plea agreement says he could be subject to roughly five to six years in prison, with a major caveat: If he provides the full extent of cooperation the special counsel's office requires, he can argue for a sentence of probation, and Mr. Mueller won't object.
Write to Aruna Viswanatha at Aruna.Viswanatha@wsj.com, Julie Bykowicz at julie.bykowicz@wsj.com and Del Quentin Wilber at del.wilber@wsj.com

Article.Byline: By Aruna Viswanatha, Julie Bykowicz and Del Quentin Wilber
